resources.string: 3Sufficient setback provided as per regulations between compound walls and building
3Internal roads of sufficient width available as per local building norms

3Sufficient clear space is available around the building/s for fire fighting operations and fire truck to travel freely (Access road to buildings above 15m height should be at least 12m wide. Open space on all sides of the building should be 6m and passageway to the building from the access road should be minimum 4.5m wide and clear head-room of 5m)
4Parked vehicles do not obstruct the yard fire hydrant posts and hose reel boxes
4No other obstructions in front of the hydrant posts or hose reel boxes
4Hose reels available in the hose reel boxes along with the nozzles
3Pathways and footpaths within the premises are non-slippery, without broken paving/tiles which could result in trips and falls
3The premises is generally free of slip / trip and fall hazards

3Areas where there is risk of injury are clearly demarcated (for example, low ceilings, sudden change in elevation, ongoing construction / excavation / repair work, taps and sumps in the garden, electrical fittings, plant and machinery, etc.). Where applicable through fare restrictions are in place
2Adequate external lighting (lux levels) provided in areas of likely people movement. This includes roads, walkways, pathways, parking lots, sit-out areas, etc.
2Building is provided with lightning protection and integrity is tested on regular basis
2General housekeeping within the premises is satisfactory
3Building fire protection and fighting provisions as per NBC (please refer guideline in next sheet)
5Assembly points are clearly demarcated and sufficiently away from the building
3Ramps with railings are provided for access to differently-abled people. Slope of such ramps is as per NBC requirements
1Designated smoking zones are located at a distance from the building where there is minimal possibility of entry of smoke into the building or into fresh air intakes of the HVAC system
5Escape route areas are free of any obstruction
3Segregation of vehicular and pedestrian traffic available and effective, including at gates and parking lots
3Where vehicular and pedestrian traffic paths intersect, appropriate safety precautions like \'Zebra\' crossings, speed breakers, signages, security guards, etc. provided to ensure pedestrian safety
3Footpaths or demarcated pathways are provided for roads to ensure segregation of vehicular and pedestrian movement
1Separate entry/exits and paths are provided for vehicles carrying goods (canteen supplies, building / furniture material, diesel / water tankers, waste trucks, etc.)

2In case separate exits and paths are not available, entry/exit of goods vehicles is restricted to off-peak hours when associate movement in that area is minimal and the movement of the vehicle in the premises is closely monitored by the security
1Loading / Unloading bays are provided for unloading material to / from vehicles

2Safety instructions are issued to goods vehicle drivers/cleaners by security like - observing speed limits, turning off engine while unloading/loading, handbrakes are applied and wheel-stops (wedges) are positioned when the vehicle is parked, sleeping under the vehicle is not permitted, etc.
2Speed limit signage is prominently displayed, especially at places where vehicles are likely to speed
1Blind turns have appropriate caution signage and mirrors to prevent vehicle collisions
3Sloping roads have appropriate signages / speed breakers to prevent speeding
1Associates\' use of helmets and safety belts before entry or exit from the premises are ensured
3No Parking\' zones clearly demarcated in bold signage
3No Parking\' Zones are strictly complied with
4Provision of physical isolation and locking of transformer for maintenance, tags, isolation tools or locks are available as required
1Isolation Checklist and SOP is available in the transformer area
4Preventive maintenance carried out as per defined frequency, tests like BDV, DGA, etc. conducted at least annually and records are maintained
2Adequate number of Earth pits are available (2 body earth+ 2 neutral ),marked appropriately, tested and maintained periodically and records are maintained
2Sand/rubble and secondary containment provided under the transformer
2Entry to transformer area restricted to authorized persons only, warning signs are displayed
4Fire fighting equipments are available and maintained

3Physical isolation, locking and tagging (Lock out tag out - LOTO) of transformer ensured before any maintenance work on transformer, permits to work systems followed and Permit issued for latest maintenance work and records are available
3Is the transformer located inside the building? If yes, is it oil-filled or ‘dry’ type? If it is oil type, is it located in an enclosed room with adequate ventilation?
3For Oil cooled transformers with oil storage exceeding 2000L, provision is available to empty the oil tank in an underground tank to prevent bursting of transformer in case of fire
2There are no visible signs of oil leakage on and under the transformer cooling fins
2Proper earthing is provided to transformer enclosures (wire fence and doors) and checked regularly for continuity
2Cable trenches are appropriately covered to prevent any trip and fall hazards

2Cable entry and exit points from the room are adequate protected to prevent entry of rodents or other small animals which could pose a risk to equipment and cables (physical damage or electrical short circuit)
1Cable trenches are dry and there is no water accumulation, even in the wet season
2Cable trench exits leading into other rooms / building are provided with fire sealants (sand or other fire retardant material) to prevent spread of fire from the panel room
3Fire detection and alarm systems are provided inside the panel rooms
2Adequate ventilation is provided in the panel room
2There is no evident overheating of panels (like open panel doors, provision of pedestal fans for cooling the panels, etc.)
3Housekeeping is good and there is no storage of material inside the panel room
4Adequate and appropriate fire extinguishers are provided at appropriate locations
3Rubber mats are provided in front and behind the panels and are in good condition to prevent electric shock
2Adequate earthing is provided for the electrical panel, and earth pit is regularly tested, maintained and records are available

4Appropriate PPEs are provided and are available at the point of use, in good condition and within the expiry period (for example, electrical gloves rated for the highest voltage handled, electrical safety shoes, etc.)
3The panels are labeled appropriately on the front and back sides to ensure accurate identification during maintenance or emergency
1All statutory signage is provided in the panel room
1Single-line diagram (SLD) is displayed as per Electricity Rules. Isolation checklist and procedure is available at the electrical panel
2Chart displaying actions to take in case of electrocution is available
5All electricians working in panel room are aware of the hazards and risks, are trained in safety procedures and are licensed
4Provision for emergency communication is available inside the panel room
3All safety interlocks and alarms are operational and maintained on regular basis
2Trained and certified technicians are deployed for Operating and Maintenance of DG sets
2Preventive maintenance schedules are maintained as per manufacturer\'s specifications and followed to ensure safe operation
2Earth pits are marked appropriately, tested and maintained periodically and records are maintained
3Rubber floor mats provided near electrical panels to prevent electric shock and are in good condition
2Proper acoustic enclosures are provided as per law and are effective
1DG noise level (as per defined frequency) test conducted and noise level is within prescribed limits (workplace noise)
3Emergency stops of the DG is in working condition and regularly tested
2Operators/technicians use ear protection when DG is running
2Operators/technicians use PPEs (Gloves, safety shoes etc) during DG maintenance work
2Arrangement is available for issuing PPEs to visitors and warning signs displayed
3Unauthorized entry to DG area prohibited
2Rotating machine parts and hot areas provided with guarding to ensure zero access
2Provision of proper access arrangements for stack monitoring porthole (with fall protection)
2Starter batteries (lead-acid) for DG sets are in good condition with no signs of crust formation at the leads or acid spillages or leakages
3Level gauge on diesel day tanks made of toughened glass with protective casing (instead of PVC tubing)
3Air vents on day tanks are inspected and maintained on regular basis
2Manual transfer of diesel from drums to the day tank is carried out using hand-operated pump
3Proper earthing continuity is provided between the hand pump and day tank to facilitate discharge of static charges generated during diesel transfer operations
4Adequate Fire detection /fighting arrangements such as detectors, sand buckets, fire extinguishers (foam type) available and maintained in usable condition
3Smoking and use of mobiles prohibited near diesel storage area and requisite warning signage is displayed
2Adequate containment / bunding arrangement for diesel storage is provided
2Arrangement for collection, storage and disposal of waste lube oil, oil soaked cotton waste etc as per Hazardous Waste (Management, Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008
3DG housing and diesel storage areas are provided with fire proof electrical installations (like lighting arrangements)
4Emergency lighting is provided in the DG area
3No storage of combustible materials like paper, plastic, etc. in DG room, good house keeping is maintained
3Earthing arrangements provided at bulk diesel storage tanks for use during diesel unloading
2All the flanges in the diesel pipeline have adequate earthing.
2Spill collection and cleaning kits provided at bulk diesel storage area
3Air vent on bulk diesel storage tank inspected and tested on regular basis
2Wire mesh provided at the mouth of the air vent to prevent entry of sparks (leading to fire)
4Appropriate and adequate fire extinguishers provided in the diesel storage area
1"Wheel-Stops" provided near bulk diesel tank for use when diesel tanker is parked during diesel unloading
1Diesel storage drums are in proper condition (not deformed or rusted) with lids secured
3There are no sources of ignition near diesel storage and handling areas
2Single line wiring diagrams, Isolation checklist and procedure is available at the electric panels
1For bulk diesel storage (above 1000 L), CCOE license is available and displayed
2DG stack port is not in the path of the indoor air circulation (the gas emissions should not enter into the AHU area)
1Emergency signages are adequate if located in an enclosed area
3Proper access ways ( walk ways, ladders, platforms etc.)are provided for inspection and daily maintenance
3There are no slip / trip and fall hazards in the area
2All ladders / walk ways / stairs in good condition
3Appropriate fall protection / railing/guarding arrangements are provided wherever there is a risk of fall from height or fall into water
2Ladders are checked and checklist and report maintained
2All moving machine parts are guarded and cannot be accessed while machine is in operation.
2Adequate ventilation (passive or forced) arrangement are provided to prevent build-up of toxic and noxious gases and provide working comfort to operators
2Proper PPEs are used by STP operator/staff whenever required (hand, ear, eye, foot protection)
3Electrical distribution boards, panels and electrical outlets in STP area in good condition and maintained regularly
2Labeled Isolation checklist and procedure is available at all electric panels
1Noise levels from STP equipment ( air blowers, compressors, pumps, etc.) is within prescribed limits
2Toxic and hazardous chemicals like Na-hypochlorite, alum, hydrogen peroxide, water treatment chemicals, etc., stored in designated areas with proper labeling
2Operators are trained on chemical handling, safety precautions and Do\'s and Don\'ts in case of chemical exposure
3Areas where there is risk of injury are clearly demarcated (for example, low ceilings, sudden change in elevation etc.)
3Water storage tanks (underground as well as terrace) are cleaned, chlorinated and maintenance records maintained
3Water treatment and purification system are cleaned and maintained on a defined frequency and maintenance records are available
3Potability of water is tested as per TCS predefined frequency and records maintained
3Water tanks (all enclosed tanks with man hole access)are identified as confined space and work permit system is followed
2Contract staff working in confined spaces are trained and records are maintained
3Suitable rescue equipment (e.g. ladders) is available to rescue the personnel from the confined spaces if needed
3Safe entry procedures detailed in the confined space work permit are briefed to the employee before starting the underground water tank operation.
3Same procedure is followed for other confined spaces in the facility like narrow utility shafts/ducts, cable trenches, fuel/chemical tanks, underground tanks with manhole entry etc.
4There are safe means of access/egress from confined space
4Flame proof low voltage lighting is available for work inside confined space
4Suitable atmosphere/gas testing facility is available for confined space work
4Breathing apparatus is available for the confined space work
2There are no slip/trip and fall hazards in the work areas
2Machine guarding is in place with no access to moving parts which could lead to injuries
2There are no sharp edges on machines and other infrastructure
2No loose cables or wires running across the floor which could cause trips and falls
1Suitable storage for tools ,tackles and spare equipment is provided
2All tools are in good condition
3Suitable storage for hazardous and inflammable materials
3All materials are labeled and stored without posing trip and fall hazard
2Portable gas cylinders are stored upright and secured
3Material is properly stored without posing trip and fall hazard
1Storage areas for material, including scrap are clearly demarcated and storage is organized well with aisles / access paths provided between storage racks for easy access
2All ladders / walk ways / stairs in good condition
2All portable ladders are identified with an unique identification number and these are periodically tested and records maintained
1Elevated platforms, if any, are protected with guard rails and toe guards
2Lifting equipment is inspected / tested and certified by competent authority
3All users of lifting equipment had appropriate training ,records are maintained
1All lifting equipment (fork lifts, davits, etc )identified with a unique number
2There a system to enable the user to identify the test status of the lifting equipment e.g. color code
2All lifting equipment clearly marked with a safe working load
3Electrical distribution boards and outlets are in good condition with no visible signs of mechanical damage or electrical sparking
2Doors of all electrical distribution panels are closed and single line diagrams, isolation checklist and procedure is available
3Rubber floor mats provided near electrical panels ( main as well as chiller panel)
2All electrical equipment is properly earthed; single earthing for equipment operating at 230V and double earthing for 415V
3Electrical protection systems like fuses, MCBs, ELCBs are provided at appropriate locations and they are tested at periodic intervals
3No \'re-wireable\' fuses are used in the facility
2Earth Pits are marked, pit resistance is checked and maintained on regular basis and records are maintained.
3There are no open electrical terminations (especially in cases where the equipment has been taken away for maintenance or replacement)
1There are no oil or other liquid spillages on the floor
2All O and M activities are carried out by trained personnel and evidence of training is available
3Safety protection on machines (safety switches, trip devices etc.) is not bypassed or made non-operational
2All hot surfaces are guarded/appropriately marked
2All chilled water conveying systems are properly insulated, marked and there is no risk of cold burns
2All openings in the floor (sumps, drains, cable trenches, etc.) are appropriately closed and pose no trip hazard
2Are cooling towers and condensers cleaned and maintained to prevent risk associated with Legionella bacteria?
2Are proper access ways provided for inspection and maintenance of cooling tower
2Noise level test conducted and noise level is within prescribed limits (workplace noise)
2Operators/technicians are using PPEs (ear muff, gloves, safety shoes etc.) while working near the operating equipment
2Emergency stops on all machines are easily accessible, are in working condition and regularly tested
1Adequate illumination is provided in the work areas, suitable to the type of activity being performed
4Fire detection and alarm systems are provided in the utility and plant room areas and is in working condition
3Emergency lighting is provided and in working condition
4Emergency Exit signages are provided at all locations and easily visible
4Exits and escape routes are clear
3Only less than 100Kg of LPG is stored (if license is not obtained), all other cylinders are connected to the manifold.
2Empty cylinders are capped and separate secure storage is available.
1LPG license requirements / conditions of the explosive license are complied with (Applicable to the gas banks with more than 100 Kgs of LPG storage)
3LPG gas leak detector is suitably mounted, maintained and tested regularly.
2Clear indication of gas storage displayed in front of the LPG bank, No smoking and no mobile signs are displayed
2No parking of vehicles is enforced in front of LPG bank
3Emergency shut off valve for LPG is provided out side the LPG bank, easily accessible, appropriately marked and operating signage displayed.
2LPG leakage emergency procedures are available and security, admin and canteen supervisor are aware of emergency procedures.
2Unauthorized entry to LPG bank area is prohibited, " Prohibited area" signage is displayed.
2Kitchen preparation area and cooking area is not slippery and proper drain arrangements are provided to avoid water stagnation
2All kitchen floors and equipment are clean and free of debris.
2Appropriate gear and tools are provided to the kitchen staff to avoid heat stress and direct contact with hot surfaces. Hot surfaces are identified and clearly marked.
2Adequate ventilation/exhaust/cooling arrangements are provided to reduce heat / smoke exposure to kitchen staff
2All staff are wearing head gear, gloves, appropriate shoes and other PPEs(wherever required)
3Electrical equipment is inspected periodically, maintained and all moving parts, nip points are suitably guarded.
3All Electrical machines have joint free cables and appropriate terminations.
3Emergency shut off valve for LPG is provided in the kitchen area, easily accessible, appropriately marked and operating signage displayed.
3LPG gas leak detector is suitably mounted in the kitchen area, maintained and tested regularly. Kitchen staff is trained on emergency procedures in case of LPG leakage

3Fire detection and fire fighting arrangements are adequate. Fire extinguishers are serviced at regular intervals and service records are available. Kitchen staff is trained on fire extinguisher usage.
2Storage of raw food items and cooked food items is as per temperature requirements specified in TCS canteen guidelines
2Adequate staking arrangement is been provided in the store rooms (dry, raw, chillers etc). All articles are stored properly with less risk of falling objects or storage racks.
2Food hygiene and personal hygiene checks are conducted as per the TCS canteen guidelines are records are maintained.
3Glass doors at the entrance are not completely transparent and provided with translucent or opaque strips or designs for easy identification of closed doors
2Path of sliding glass doors (if any) is clear and there is no likelihood of inadvertent obstruction by any person or object
2Safety signage displayed near X-ray screening machines to prevent any inadvertent radiation exposure or injury to fingers due to entrapment between rollers (to associates as well as security staff)
1Basement parking areas are adequately illuminated as per NBC / BEE standards
3Emergency lights are provided in the basement area
2Workplaces are smoke-free zones with appropriate signage displayed
2There are no slip / trip and fall hazards
2"Do Not Use the Lifts in the Event of Fire" notice displayed in the lift lobby
1Lift license displayed inside the lift cabin as per Lift regulations
1Lift maintenance carried out at regular intervals (preventive) and records maintained
2Safety instructions displayed inside the lift cabin
1Escalators are maintained and tested and records available
2Emergency light is provided in the lift and is in working condition
2Window Cradles, eyebolts and access equipment maintained and tested, the records are available
3No slip / trip and fall hazards present in the staircase
2Hand rails provided in the staircases on both sides
3Any uneven step risers or treads are demarcated to draw the user\'s attention
2Treads are non-slippery or provided with slip-resistant tape to prevent slips and falls
2Edges of treads are not chipped or broken which could lead to trips and falls
2In case of possibility of slipping through the sides of the staircase, toe-guards are provided
1Any openings in the side walls of the staircase are adequately protected to prevent any person slipping through
2Pest Control is carried out on regular basis and records are maintained
3Electrical extension boards are not used unless certified by the electrician (for temporary use only)
1All access to roofs, terraces are controlled/ manned by security personnel
3Combustible materials are properly stored, away from sources of ignition like electrical connections / outlets or equipment
3Office furniture, carpets, false ceiling and other interiors are made of materials that are either fire retardant or do not contribute to rapid spread of fire
4Fire dampers in the AC ducts are operational in case of fire which helps in preventing spread of smoke through the AC ducts
3Hydrant riser cupboards and service ducts locked and free from combustible materials
4The building has a fully integrated maintained automatic fire detection and alarm system (addressable system consisting of smoke/heat detectors, manual call points, sounders and control panel)

4For multi-occupancy buildings, TCS\' fire detection and alarm system is integrated with the overall building\'s fire detection and alarm system so that fire in any other premises of the building gets communicated to TCS
5The fire detection and alarm system is fully operational covering all parts of the building
5The fire detection and alarm system including manual call points is under AMC. Testing, inspection and maintenance are carried out as per schedule
5The fire detection and alarm system has adequate back-up power source
4Fire alarm call points and any other means of raising the alarm, unobstructed and positioned near fire escape routes on each floor (about 1.4m above floor level)
5Space above the false ceiling provided with detectors and connected to fire detection and alarm system
4Fire alarm audible throughout the building (strobe warning lights provided for areas where noise affects audibility of alarm e.g. Plant and machine rooms)
5The fire escape routes are adequately lit and provided with emergency lighting (internally and externally) and free of obstructions and material that can aid the spread of fire
4Luminescent marking is provided along emergency evacuation routes as per the HSE Signage Standards
4Emergency exits are not blocked or locked preventing easy evacuation during an emergency
5Fire doors are normally kept closed to prevent spread of smoke and fire into emergency escape staircases (particularly applicable to common staircases in multi-occupancy buildings)
3Floor numbers are clearly marked in the stairwell in luminescent signage
5No main gas piping, electrical shafts, A/C duct passing through or opening in staircase/s. No floor or main electrical panel present in staircase/s.
4In case external escape staircase is provided, fire resistant door is provided and adequate distances from windows and walls (within 1.8m horizontally and 9m vertically below part of the stairway)
3The external escape staircase (if any) protected from weather effects, well maintained and provided with slip-resistant material
5Fire exits lead to a place of safety away from the building
5Openings to emergency exit staircase/s (except ground floor) provided with fire rated doors of at least ½ hour rating
4Fire rated doors to fire escape routes easily operable and not bolted or locked
3All doors on the fire escape route open in the direction of travel
5Adequate fire extinguishers available and placed appropriately (so that a person does not have to travel more than 15 m to access one)
5Fire extinguishers are easily accessible (free of obstructions)
5If sprinklers provided, they have been maintained and tested
3Internal hydrant points, hose reels are free of obstructions
3Fire fighting system and equipment is under AMC and maintenance is carried out as per schedule
2Doors of electrical distribution panels are properly secured to prevent unauthorized access
1Single line wiring diagrams, Isolation checklist and procedure is available at all electric panels
2There are no visible signs of overheating / smoke stains near or inside electrical distribution panels
4There is no storage of items inside the distribution panel enclosure
4Smoke detectors are provided in the distribution panel enclosures and are operational
3Protective devices like MCBs, RCCBs, HRC fuses are installed, tested and maintained for preventing short-circuits, overloads, leakage currents and surges
4Electrical wiring / cabling is of FRLS, HFFR type which prevents rapid spread of fire and generates less smoke in the event of fire
3All electrical conduits are of rigid PVC or metal
4Electrical DBs and circuits are appropriately labeled for easy identification
2Floors near water coolers / dispensers / beverage vending machines / pantries are dry and free of any slip hazards
2Adequate illumination (lux levels) is provided in the common areas (as per NBC / BEE guidelines)
3Emergency lights in the corridors / passages / staircases are marked and specific maintenance protocol exists for such lights
1All ducts and shafts are properly locked and secured so that there is no possibility of entry of unauthorized persons
2Gratings are provided at all floor levels in the shafts and ducts to prevent falls
2Provision for illumination is available in the shafts and ducts in case of any maintenance work
3Electrical shafts have fire and smoke stops / seals provided at all floor openings to prevent vertical spread of fire and smoke
3Openings for horizontal cable entries within the building are sealed to prevent spread of smoke and fire
1There is a preventive maintenance schedule for all machinery and equipment and it is strictly adhered to
2Regular rounds by maintenance personnel to monitor operating equipment (to spot any safety hazards)
2Maintenance personnel are aware of and adopt safe work procedures during O and M of machinery / equipment
2Maintenance personnel are aware of and use designated PPEs
2Work permit system is in place and implemented
3All electrical installations and portable electrical tools/equipment are maintained, tested and in good condition and the records of testing / inspection / calibration are available
2Lock-Out Tag-Out procedure is in place and implemented in areas where hazardous energy is present (for example, electricity, air or water pressure, etc.)
2AHU rooms are locked to prevent unauthorized entry
5AHU rooms are free of clutter and storage of any material
3Shock prevention arrangements such as rubber mats are provided near the electrical panel
2Emergency lights are provided in the AHU room.
2Noise levels outside AHU rooms is tested and within acceptable limits for indoor noise
1There are no perceptible vibrations in the areas (floor / walls) within and adjoining the AHU rooms
4Smoke detectors are provided in the AHU Rooms
2Limit switches are provided for AHU doors so that the AHU trips in case any door of the AHU is opened. Also, the AHU does not start until the doors are closed
1Adequate and designated storage spaces are available
1Separate storage areas are provided for housekeeping chemicals, supplies, equipment spares and other items. Proper segregation of material is done

1Separate designated space is provided for old IT equipment, electrical items and luminaries, lead-acid batteries and adequate controls are in place that they do not pose and safety or environmental hazard
2Stacking of material is done in shelves or cupboards. In case material is stacked one over other, the stacks are reasonable in height, stable and not at risk of collapsing causing injury.
2Shelves are in good condition without any bends or deformations (leading to loss in bearing capacity)
4Storage of combustible scrap is kept to a minimum and in designated areas. Adequate fire fighting devices (fire extinguishers) are quickly accessible
2Stacking is done in neat rows with sufficient aisle space between stacks for easy handling of material and reaching the farthest stack in case of an emergency (also applies to record rooms)
2For material stacked at a height, proper ladder (aluminum, A-type) is provided
5Clear space is provided between the ceiling and top of the stack, especially near light fittings
4Fire extinguishers are available in the store rooms
4Smoke detectors are provided inside the store room.
5Emergency exits are clearly marked and exits are free of obstacles
5Adequate fire fighting / extinguishing arrangements are provided such as FM 200, Novec etc. as applicable
2Adequate caution boards and signages are displayed outside the data center about the suppression gas (as per MSDS) properties and precautions that need to be taken
2Proper instructions are given informing the type of activation (auto or manual)
4Control buttons are marked very clearly with colour codes and authorized persons including security trained on suppression gas activation and deactivation
3Lone working is not permitted and a \'buddy system\' is followed in case work has to be carried out in the room for long durations
4Fire suppression systems are inspected and monitored as per defined frequency and in working condition, heat / smoke detectors are not capped / covered.
5No material storage in the hub/server rooms/data center
4Adequate and appropriate fire extinguishers are provided
1Ramps leading to server rooms / data centers have requisite slope (1:12) and have slip resistant flooring
4Proper temperature maintained in the UPS room to avoid over heating of batteries
2All wires are properly insulated and no worn out/ naked electric wires
2No acid leakages from batteries or crusted leads
2Proper earthing arrangements (including battery rack )provided and earthpit records maintained
4Adequate fire detection/extinguishing equipment provided
3Insulated rubber mats are provided in front of the UPS panel
3Emergency lighting is provided and has an identification mark
4No items are stored inside the room
2Toilets are clean and hygienic and records of periodic cleaning are maintained
2Liquid soap dispensers and toilet rolls are replenished regularly, especially towards the end of the workday
1Wet floors are mopped immediately and there are no slip and fall hazards
1Waste bins are emptied regularly and there are no overflowing bins
1Adequate lighting levels are provided in the washroom
2Emergency lighting is provided in the washroom and is in working condition
3Aisles, passages within the work area are free of obstructions (chairs, boxes, etc.)
3No trip hazards on the floor due to open junction boxes, upturned carpet edges or loose cables across the floor
3Sharp corners that could injure people are eliminated by providing proper cover
3Sudden changes in floor elevation or steps are clearly identified and marked
4Signages for exits are adequate in numbers, size and visible from all locations in the module

3Instruction notices detailing the actions to take in an emergency and floor plans showing the fire escape route and location of fire extinguishers on prominent display (e.g. meeting rooms, notice boards)
4Emergency lights provided and in working condition, identified and marked
2Ceiling is free of hazards from missing tiles, holes and water damage
2Precautions in place to stop people/ materials falling from open edges
5Adequate fire extinguishers provided in designated locations, easy to reach and without any obstructions
4Fire extinguishers are routinely maintained

3Workplace temperature maintained at 24 + 1 degrees C uniformly throughout the floorWorkplace temperature maintained at 24 + 1 degrees C uniformly throughout the floorWorkplace temperature maintained at 24 + 1 degrees C uniformly throughout the floor
3No storage of boxes, files or papers below the desk
3Adequate lighting levels as per NBC / BEE standards maintained in all work areas
3First Aid boxes with approved contents provided
3First Aid boxes do not contain date-expired items
4Adequate number of First Aiders available (1 for 50 or fewer people; more than 100 people – 1 additional First Aider per 100 people)
3"Emergency telephone numbers" are displayed in prominent places
3Fire Committee Organization Chart with names and contact details are displayed in all floors/ODCs
2Identification signage is provided for Floor Marshalls for easy contact
4Associates understand fire emergency procedures and new employees have received emergency preparedness awareness induction at the workplace
3Ergonomically compliant workstations and chairs have been provided to all associates
2Workstations are regularly cleaned
2Openable/Slidable windows (if any) are securely locked
2Floor tiles are not slippery
2Display screen equipment is placed at appropriate positions on the desks
2Associates demonstrate general awareness of ergonomic work postures
4Adequate number of exits are provided for each module meeting NBC requirements
5All secured doors of exits get deactivated in case of an emergency alarm
5All doors of emergency and other exits open outwards to facilitate speedy evacuation
3All exits (including emergency exits) are free of obstructions, slip / trip and fall hazards and accessible at all times
3Travel distances to nearest exits are adequate as per NBC requirements (18m for single exit, 30m for more than one exit for non-sprinklered and 45m for sprinklered building)
4Exits are of sufficient width to accommodate the safe evacuation of people (900mm up to 100 persons, 1050mm for up to 200 persons and additional 75mm for every additional 15 persons over 200)
3All contractor staff have received induction training and records are available
2Contractor work is adequately supervised by nominated supervisors
3Supervisors conduct safety briefing for staff on regular basis
2Documented work procedures are available with contractors for high risk activities
3Lock-Out Tag-Out system is followed for all maintenance activities involving hazardous energy
3Safety signage / Caution Boards are used for marking temporary hazards? (e.g. caution – wet floor)
2All portable electrical tools (drills, etc.) are in good condition with double body earthing. The earthing is tested for continuity on periodic basis
2All contractor equipment brought to site is periodically inspected or when it is deployed at site
2Appropriate signages are provided for highlighting potential hazards
2Housekeeping in the DG room/enclosure, chiller plant room and other utility areas is good
2Storage areas for material, including scrap are clearly demarcated and storage is organized well with aisles / access paths provided between storage racks for easy access
4All contractor staff have received emergency preparedness training and records are available
2Persons working at height are medically fit to do so and Internal assurance is in place
2Scaffolding is erected by trained and competent personnel
1Scaffolds are periodically fitness tested, tagged and records are maintained
2All vertical ladders over 10 m are provided with fall protection system (ladder cage, life line etc.)
3Procedure in place to barricade the area below the work at height and placement of signages
2Fall prevention/ fall arrest harness systems are registered and tested
2Ladders, scaffolds, fall protection equipment are tested periodically and records are maintained
2Safety cages are provided on fixed vertical ladders over 2.5 meters
1Access to vertical ladders is only for authorized persons
1Work areas above 90 dBA are clearly designated with signage
2High noise level area (85 dBA) is reviewed for the noise reduction
2The use of hearing protection is audited/inspected
2Suitable hearing protection is provided for above dBA and ensured it is worn all the time.
2Staff are trained on noise at work and safe work practice
2Regular hearing checks are carried out for all employees at risk and records are maintained
3Permit-to-work system is followed for relevant activities (hot work, electrical work, etc.)
3Safety measures are available as mentioned in work permit
3Briefing is done on hazards and safe working before issue of work permit
2Work permits are used only for a single shift and displayed during work
2License or competency are checked for contractors before carrying out the work
1PPE requirements are identified for all the jobs and a list is available
2All PPEs in use are appropriate for the nature of work performed and in good condition
2Adequate number of PPEs are available at site and stored appropriately
2Employees are given information/ instruction /training on how to use and care for PPE
3All jobs have been evaluated for manual handling needs
2Lifting aids have been provided for the jobs requiring hoisting more than 25 Kgs
2Employees are trained on safe manual handling techniques
4Emergency evacuation drills are conducted on quarterly basis
4Fire Wardens are appointed for each floor (minimum 2 for each floor)
4Roles and responsibilities for fire emergencies clearly defined and understood by Fire Wardens / Marshals
5Fire Wardens and Marshals received the appropriate fire safety training
5Arrangements are in place for the safe evacuation of mobility impaired / disabled staff / expectant mothers
5Visitors are given information with regard to fire and other emergency arrangements when they arrive on site
4Floor Plan is displayed showing the fire escape routes and locations of fire fighting equipment
4Fire exit doors are marked internally as well as externally with the appropriate signs to indicate that the door should not be obstructed
4Fire extinguisher locations are clearly indicated with appropriate signage
4Names and contact numbers of Fire Marshall / Fire Wardens have been displayed at prominent locations
3Certified First Aiders are available and names and contact numbers are prominently displayed
4Procedure for reporting emergencies with the emergency contact numbers have been displayed at prominent locations
